content.description: Easy route with large cracks and rock outcroppings for holds. BEWARE: there is a large flake about 2/3 of the way up that is cracked on the left side from the top of the flake to the bottom of the flake. It seems like several hundred pounds of rock is ready to fall at any time. Avoid using this flake.
content.protection:
4 bolts to anchors with rap chains.

Top rope could be set from anchors by walking around to the top (very easy 1 min hike).

content.description: Start up a short crack with blocky holds just left of the 10c and right of M&M.  From the crack go straight up through some rock with cool features but a little grungy to its own anchors.  Great climbing!
content.location: Just right of M&M and just left of the 10c.

climbs.name: Scale Wall
climbs.fa: Norman Boles and George Watson, late 80's or early 90's

content.description:
Climb the second route from the right on the Scale wall, just to the left of

Landslide

(5.8).

Climbing is sustained up the crack, keep moving so you don't run out of gas! Well protected, though still dirty in the top sections.

The top of the route is considerably simpler, but you've got 45 feet of traversy crack before you get there!
content.protection: 7 bolts to a 2 bolt top anchor.  Walk around the right of the rock to gain access to the top anchors for a top rope.

content.description: starts on some side pulls probably 10 feet right of the "Unknown 5.9" on the left side of scale wall. Climb up crimps and side pulls with the occasional good foot up to the little tree sticking out of a crack. This is a little more than half way up the wall, from there join the 5.9 to the left around the third bolt and climb to the top.
content.protection: climb the "unknown 5.9" and set up a top rope from its anchors.
content.location: left of the 10b, right of the 5.9. Under and slightly left of the little tree half way up the wall.

content.description:
Fifth route from the left on the scale wall. Climb up the slab using huge jugs with good feet. This climb is stretchy enough where it will be a good warm up, and a good exercise for someone who hasn't climbed outdoors before.

The route is a bit runout for a 5.8, but the crux is protected and near the top.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a 2 bolt top anchor.

content.description:
Climb the bolted route on the extreme right of the Scale wall.

Climbing is simple and well protected, though there is still tons of loose rock on this route.  You will feel like you're going to trigger a landslide!

Crux is in the slightly overhung section at the top, though the holds are still quite good.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  Don't use anything less than a 50 m rope on this route!

content.description: Start up the pillar on good rails.  Big holds separated by big moves.
content.location: Farthest left on the Scale Wall.

content.description: Start up easy ramp and cracks.  Above this is an awkward section of liebacking that eventually eases to cool face moves.  The last sequence involves a mono pull!
content.location: Right of the ramp crack of Three Finger Salute.

content.description:
This is currently the fourth bolted route from the left on the scale wall.

Getting past the first two bolts is definitely the crux, so be confident in your abilities.

Climb up through a committing first section to easier climbing above.  Past the second bolt, this route is probably a 5.8.
